misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array boundaries and indices derived from the dynamic size N (like N-1 or N-2) are abstract or difficult to manage directly within loop condition or indexing expressions. Thus, they must first calculate these indices (a, b, c) and store them in dedicated variables to safeguard against potential off-by-one errors and clarify the role of the boundary.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The Java execution model handles simple arithmetic expressions (like N-1 or N-2) within loop constructs and array indexing calls perfectly and consistently. The student's approach, while correct, suggests a lack of confidence or security concerning in-line index calculation, which unnecessarily complicates the code and introduces redundant variables for constant values.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Off-by-One Index Miscalculation in Loop Bounds
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that by starting the loop at index N-2 and decrementing to 0, they will shift all elements correctly one position to the right. They think this loop will cover all necessary elements that need to be shifted.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student has miscalculated the loop bounds. When shifting right, the loop should iterate from index N-1 down to index 1 (not 0), because we only want to move existing elements one position right. Starting at N-2 and going to 0 means the loop executes one too many times. The loop condition i >= c where c = 0 causes the loop to attempt an assignment at arr[0 + 1] = arr[0], which overwrites arr[1] with arr[0] after arr[0] should have already been set to last.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. The algorithm fails to shift all elements correctly. Elements do not end up in the expected positions, and the wrapping behavior is broken.

evidence.code_snippet: int b = N - 2; int c = 0; for (int i = b; i >= c; i--) { arr[i + 1] = arr[i]; }
for (int i = b; i >= c; i--)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that starting the backward loop at i = N-2 and stopping at i = 0 correctly covers all elements that need to be shifted right.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: For a right shift operation, when copying elements backward from right to left, the loop should go from i = N-1 down to i = 1. Going down to i = 0 causes the code to process one too many elements. The actual Java execution model requires careful iteration bounds: shifting right from index 0 to N-1 means we must copy starting from the rightmost elements and work leftward to avoid overwriting data we still need. The loop bounds chosen (N-2 down to 0) do not respect this constraint correctly.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. The shift operation produces an incorrect array because one element gets overwritten incorrectly.

evidence.code_snippet: int b = N - 2; int c = 0; for (int i = b; i >= c; i--) { arr[i + 1] = arr[i]; }

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that their loop correctly shifts elements to the right while preserving the value of the last element to wrap around to the front. The logic involves saving the last element and then iterating backward, copying `arr[i]` into `arr[i+1]` to avoid overwriting needed values.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There is no conceptual gap. The student's understanding of sequential execution, variable state, and array indexing is correct in this section. They correctly identified the need to save the tail element before starting the shift and then iterate backward to avoid data corruption.
